Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Shape Memory Polymer Based Orthopedic Fixation Devices
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project includes the design, development and commercialization of shape memory polymer orthopedic soft-tissue fixation devices. Current soft tissue fixation devices are primarily metal or plastic screws used to attach tissue grafts to bone in repair of torn anterior cruciate ligaments (ACL). These threaded devices commonly damage the tendon during insertion; reducing the effectiveness of the surgery. Shape memory polymers are a superior solution in that they can provide a simpler, stronger, and less damaging fixation method for these tendon grafts. Essentially, a shape memory polymer device can be; (1) delivered into the body in a compacted and less invasive state, (2) self-deploy at body temperature and (3) do so without sharp edges that might damage the tissue.

The proposed work has immediate commercial potential and direct societal benefit in the field of sports medicine with a significant market on the order of $210 million in ACL repair devices annually. Furthermore, the biomaterial developed for ACL reconstruction should have long-term impact on the 1.6MM orthopedic procedures performed each year to repair tendons and ligaments in knees, shoulders, and ankles and by reducing the invasiveness of surgery and improving the outcomes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcome:

This SBIR project aimed to develop surgical implants based on shape memory polymers. The work culminated in the successful commercialization of a shape memory polymer device intended for Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) knee reconstruction. The resulting product derived from this technology was cleared for sale by the US Food and Drug Administration in November, 2010. First human use was completed in January, 2011. Additional product offerings (sizes, etc) have been developed and full market release is scheduled for July, 2011.

Background / Explanation:

Interference screws commercially available for soft tissue reconstruction can result in damage to grafts used to repair injuries during their implantation; limiting the surgeries long-term efficacy and hampering the overall post-operative healing process. The shape memory polymer device developed under the NSF SBIR grant has no sharp edges that could damage the graft during implantation, and provides for even, uniform pressure on the graft, increasing the likelihood of successful reintegration with bone. In addition, the use of shape memory materials allows for a smaller size of the implant during use and a deployed shape much larger than the initial shape upon insertion, reducing the overall invasiveness of the procedure itself.

Intellectual Merit (technical significance):

The intellectual merit of the ongoing work rests on the fundamental scientific knowledge gained regarding the design of shape memory polymer orthopedic devices as well as the process development and production of these devices in volume. The shape memory polymers commonly available today do not have the strength to function in orthopedic applications. The development of this new class of shape memory polymers provides a system whereby substantial forces can be generated during shape recovery of the polymeric device; allowing it to be utilized in new and unique ways.

Broader Impact:

The broader impact of the completed work hinged on the commercial release of an improved, commercially viable solution for soft tissue repair in reconstruction surgery. The new device resulting from this NSF funded technology provides for less invasive surgical techniques as well as the potential for improved healing post-operatively. In addition, the shape memory polymer material can be used to benefit a variety of orthopedic applications, including suture anchors for the repair of torn tendons and as support for small bone fractures to improve healing and eliminate the need for external casts. Additional development work has begun to leverage the advantages of this technology in reducing the invasiveness and improving efficacy of treatment for various spinal disorders and injuries.

The research was been conducted in partnership with the Georgia Institute of Technology whereby, over the past three years, 18 co-operative education students have been employed under or sponsored in support of this grant. As such, these students have had the opportunity to learn more about biomechanics and the medical industry as a whole. Since students are biomedical, materials science and mechanical engineers, their experience has been relevant to their chosen career path(s). As a result of it’s support of the co-operative education program at Georgia Tech, MedShape Solutions, Inc. was named co-op employer of the year for 2010.
